jobsToBeDone.description: The business situation or operating environment.
jobsToBeDone.example: “Quarterly close process across distributed finance teams.”

jobsToBeDone.description: Breakdowns, inefficiencies, or risks that trigger the search.
jobsToBeDone.example: “Errors in revenue recognition delaying financial reporting.”

jobsToBeDone.description: Internal and external forces moving them toward or away from change.
jobsToBeDone.example: “CFO pressure to modernize systems vs. IT reluctance to add new vendors.”

jobsToBeDone.description: Concerns about adopting something new, and inertia with current processes/tools.
jobsToBeDone.example: “Fear of migration failure; comfort with spreadsheets.”

jobsToBeDone.description: Business goals and success metrics they want to achieve.
jobsToBeDone.example: “Reduce audit prep time by 50%; ensure SOX compliance.”

jobsToBeDone.description: Minimum standards a solution must meet to even be considered.
jobsToBeDone.example: “SOC2 compliance, API integrations with ERP, enterprise-grade security.”

jobsToBeDone.description: Differentiators that make them select one vendor.
jobsToBeDone.example: “Proven implementation playbook; reference customers in financial services.”

jobsToBeDone.description: Triggers that get a vendor rejected or replaced.
jobsToBeDone.example: “System downtime; lack of role-based access control.”
“May sacrifice customization for faster time to value.”

customerValue.description: The non-negotiables for credibility. If you don’t have them, you’re out. These are compliance, security, reliability, and integration standards every enterprise expects.
The tangible, measurable business outcomes. This is the hard ROI—efficiency gains, cost savings, revenue growth, or risk mitigation.
customerValue.example: “$500K OpEx savings validated by faster close cycles and error-rate reduction.”

customerValue.description: How simple you make adoption and use. Enterprise buyers weigh friction. A solution that’s easier to buy, implement, and run often beats a “better” product.
customerValue.example: “Fast implementation playbook, role-based onboarding, 24/7 enterprise support.”

customerValue.description: What matters to each stakeholder in the buying group. Individual Value addresses what each one personally gains—status, confidence, workload relief, or career upside.
customerValue.example: “CFO is seen as innovator; IT leader feels secure in system stability; end users save hours of manual work.”

customerValue.description: Alignment with vision and purpose. Higher-order motivations that make a vendor strategic.
customerValue.example: “Supports ESG reporting goals; positions company as a digital leader; signals innovation to board and investors.”

willingnessToPay.description: Whether the customer has budget and capacity to spend. Even high-value solutions fail without available budget or a way to fund them.
willingnessToPay.example: “Line item already approved in FY25 budget for compliance automation.”

willingnessToPay.description: Whether the ROI and payback case makes financial sense. Customers want proof the investment will pay for itself within an acceptable time horizon.
willingnessToPay.example: “Pays for itself in under 12 months through $1M annual cost avoidance.”

willingnessToPay.description: How your solution compares to competitors or the status quo. If your product delivers clearer, differentiated outcomes, willingness to pay rises.
willingnessToPay.example: “Automates 80% of manual work versus consultant-heavy models.”

willingnessToPay.description: How much risk or friction they see in making the change. Higher risk perception or switching pain lowers willingness to pay; clear mitigation raises it.
willingnessToPay.example: “Migration takes days, not months; vendor assumes implementation risk.”

willingnessToPay.description: The pricing anchors customers bring from prior spend or competitors. Buyers rarely assess value in a vacuum; they benchmark against what “similar” tools cost.
willingnessToPay.example: “Analytics platforms in this space usually run $100K–$150K annually.”
